plausible_answers.text: render them the dominant demographic force in New York Jewry

qas.question: What does the NY Times claim that the rate of growth for non-Orthodox Jews will eventually mean?

context: In contrast to the general American Jewish community, which is <b5_0>dwindling<b5_0/> due to low fertility and high intermarriage and assimilation rates, the Orthodox Jewish community of the United States is growing rapidly. Among <b7_0>Orthodox Jews<b7_0/>, the fertility rate stands at about <a1_0><b6_0>4.1 children<a1_0/> per family<b6_0/>, as compared to <a0_0>1.9 children<a0_0/> per family among non-Orthodox Jews, and intermarriage among Orthodox Jews is practically non-existent, standing at about <a2_0>2%<a2_0/>, in contrast to a <a3_0>71%<a3_0/> intermarriage rate among non-Orthodox Jews. In addition, Orthodox Judaism has a growing <b8_0>retention rate<b8_0/>; while about <a4_0>half<a4_0/> of those raised in Orthodox homes previously abandoned Orthodox Judaism, that number is declining. According to The New York Times, the high growth rate of Orthodox Jews will eventually <b9_0>render them the dominant demographic force in New York Jewry<b9_0/>.
